        a class="nav-link" href="javascript:void(0)"Link/a
      /li
      li class="nav-item"
        a class="nav-link fk-disabled" href="javascript:void(0)"Disabled/a
      /li
    /ul
    form class="fk-form-inline fk-my-2 fk-my-lg-0"
      input class="fk-form-control fk-mr-sm-2" type="search" placeholder="Search" aria-label="Search"
      button class="fk-btn fk-btn-outline-success fk-my-2 fk-my-sm-0" type="submit"Search/button
    /form
  /div
/nav
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

With a brand name shown on the left and toggler on the right:

{{capture 'example'}}
nav class="navbar navbar-expand-lg navbar-light fk-bg-light"
  a class="navbar-brand" href="javascript:void(0)"Navbar/a
  button class="navbar-toggler" type="button" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#navbarTogglerDemo02" aria-controls="navbarTogglerDemo02" aria-expanded="false" aria-label="Toggle navigation"
    span class="navbar-toggler-icon"/span
  /button

  div class="fk-collapse navbar-collapse" id="navbarTogglerDemo02"

      /li

      button class="fk-btn fk-btn-outline-success fk-my-2 fk-my-sm-0" type="submit"Search/button
    /form
  /div
/nav
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

With a toggler on the left and brand name on the right:

{{capture 'example'}}
nav class="navbar navbar-expand-lg navbar-light fk-bg-light"
  button class="navbar-toggler" type="button" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#navbarTogglerDemo03" aria-controls="navbarTogglerDemo03" aria-expanded="false" aria-label="Toggle navigation"
    span class="navbar-toggler-icon"/span

External content

Sometimes you want to use the collapse plugin to trigger hidden content elsewhere on the page. Because our plugin works on the id and data-target matching, that's easily done!

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-pos-f-t"
  div class="fk-collapse" id="navbarToggleExternalContent"
    div class="fk-bg-dark fk-p-4"
      h5 class="fk-text-white fk-h4"Collapsed content/h5
      span class="fk-text-muted"Toggleable via the navbar brand./span

layout: baseof
group: components
---

# Pagination

Pagination help when dealing with lists of options that are too long to be provided on a single page. For example:
- A list of search results
- Tables with many rows that are broken down into multiple pages
- A long list of products (could also be considered table rows)
Photo galleries

![pagination-example](img/pagination-start@2x.png)


Ideally, from a usability prespective, users should be able to find what they want close to the top of the list (i.e.search results). To focus users attention is better to present a limited set of list of options (10, 20), then offer a path to pages containg more items from this list.

Relative to this, make sure filter functionality remembers the users choice, so that stays constant while the user is going through multiple pages.

This is a pagination example on 1st page


### Benefits
- It provides a quick way to move through pages
- Also, it provides the user with a sense of location, let users know where they are in the context of how many pages a list of options expand to.

---

### Dependencies
Pagination is directly related to other functionality, such as:

- Search functionality, where actually the pages that will be listed on the pagination results will directly depend on how well the search criteria is constructed, and/or how well the search engine client performs.

- Filtering functionality. For example, making a filter selection to get 10, 20, 30 results per page. The exception to this is the View All filter option, which will result on the pagination component being removed from the page.

---
layout: docs
title: Popovers
description: Documentation and examples for adding framekit popovers, like those found in iOS, to any element on your shared.
group: components
toc: true
---

Overview

Things to know when using the popover plugin:

Popovers rely on the 3rd party library Popper.js for positioning. You must include popper.min.js before framekit.js or use framekit.bundle.min.js / framekit.bundle.js which contains Popper.js in order for popovers to work!
Popovers require the tooltip plugin as a dependency.
If you're building our JavaScript from source, it requires util.js.
Popovers are opt-in for performance reasons, so you must initialize them yourself.
Zero-length title and content values will never show a popover.
Specify container: 'body' to avoid rendering problems in more complex components (like our input groups, button groups, etc).
Triggering popovers on hidden elements will not work.
Popovers for .disabled or disabled elements must be triggered on a wrapper element.
When triggered from anchors that wrap across multiple lines, popovers will be centered between the anchors' overall width. Use white-space: nowrap; on your as to avoid this behavior.
Popovers must be hidden before their corresponding elements have been removed from the DOM.

Keep reading to see how popovers work with some examples.

 Example: Enable popovers everywhere

One way to initialize all popovers on a page would be to select them by their data-toggle attribute:

{{ highlight html }}
$(function () {
  $('[data-toggle="popover"]').popover()
})
{{ /highlight }}

Example: Using the container option

When you have some styles on a parent element that interfere with a popover, you'll want to specify a custom container so that the popover's HTML appears within that element instead.

{{ highlight html }}
$(function () {
  $('.example-popover').popover({
    container: 'body'
  })
})
{{ /highlight }}

 Example

{{capture 'example'}}
button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-lg fk-btn-danger" data-toggle="popover" title="Popover title" data-content="And here's some amazing content. It's very engaging. Right?"Click to toggle popover/button
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Four directions

Four options are available: top, right, bottom, and left aligned.

div class="bd-example popover-demo"
  div class="bd-example-popovers"
    button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary" data-container="body" data-toggle="popover" data-placement="top" data-content="Vivamus sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus."
      Popover on top
    /button
    button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary" data-container="body" data-toggle="popover" data-placement="right" data-content="Vivamus sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus."
      Popover on right
    /button
    button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary" data-container="body" data-toggle="popover" data-placement="bottom" data-content="Vivamus sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus."
      Popover on bottom
    /button
    button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary" data-container="body" data-toggle="popover" data-placement="left" data-content="Vivamus sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus."
      Popover on left
    /button
  /div
/div

{{ highlight html }}
button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary" data-container="body" data-toggle="popover" data-placement="top" data-content="Vivamus sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus."
  Popover on top
/button

button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary" data-container="body" data-toggle="popover" data-placement="right" data-content="Vivamus sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus."
  Popover on right
/button

<button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary" data-container="body" data-toggle="popover" data-placement="bottom" data-content="Vivamus
sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus."
  Popover on bottom
/button

button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary" data-container="body" data-toggle="popover" data-placement="left" data-content="Vivamus sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus."
  Popover on left
/button
{{ /highlight }}

 Dismiss on next click

Use the focus trigger to dismiss popovers on the user's next click of a different element than the toggle element.

div class="bd-callout bd-callout-warning"
Specific markup required for dismiss-on-next-click

For proper cross-browser and cross-platform behavior, you must use the a tag, not the button tag, and you also must include a tabindex attribute.
/div
{{include "callout" content=callout type="danger"}}

{{capture 'example'}}
a tabindex="0" class="fk-btn fk-btn-lg fk-btn-danger" role="button" data-toggle="popover" data-trigger="focus" title="Dismissible popover" data-content="And here's some amazing content. It's very engaging. Right?"Dismissible popover/a
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

{{ highlight html }}
$('.popover-dismiss').popover({
  trigger: 'focus'
})
{{ /highlight }}

 Disabled elements

Elements with the disabled attribute aren't interactive, meaning users cannot hover or click them to trigger a popover (or tooltip). As a workaround, you'll want to trigger the popover from a wrapper div or span and override the pointer-events on the disabled element.

For disabled popover triggers, you may also prefer data-trigger="hover" so that the popover appears as immediate visual feedback to your users as they may not expect to click on a disabled element.

{{capture 'example'}}
span class="fk-d-inline-block" data-toggle="popover" data-content="Disabled popover"
  button class="fk-btn fk-btn-primary" style="pointer-events: none;" type="button" disabledDisabled button/button
/span
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Usage

Enable popovers via JavaScript:

{{ highlight html }}$('example').popover(options){{ /highlight }}

Options

Options can be passed via data attributes or JavaScript. For data attributes, append the option name to data-, as in data-animation="".

table class="fk-table fk-table-bordered fk-table-striped"
  thead
    tr
      th style="width: 100px;"Name/th

      td
        pAppends the popover to a specific element. Example: codecontainer: 'body'/code. This option is particularly useful in that it allows you to position the popover in the flow of the document near the triggering element - which will prevent the popover from floating away from the triggering element during a window resize./p
      /td
    /tr

      tdstring | element | function/td
      td''/td
      td
        pDefault content value if codedata-content/code attribute isn't present./p
        pIf a function is given, it will be called with its codethis/code reference set to the element that the popover is attached to./p
      /td
    /tr

      tdnumber | object/td
      td0/td

        pIf a number is supplied, delay is applied to both hide/show/p
        pObject structure is: codedelay: { "show": 500, "hide": 100 }/code/p
      /td
    /tr
    tr
      tdhtml/td
      tdboolean/td
      tdfalse/td
      tdInsert HTML into the popover. If false, jQuery's codetext/code method will be used to insert content into the DOM. Use text if you're worried about XSS attacks./td

        pWhen a function is used to determine the placement, it is called with the popover DOM node as its first argument and the triggering element DOM node as its second. The codethis/code context is set to the popover instance./p
      /td

See a href="https://github.com/twbs/issues/4215"this/a and a href="https://jsbin.com/zopod/1/edit"an informative example/a./td

For more information refer to Popper.js's a href="https://popper.js.org/popper-documentation.html#modifiers..preventOverflow.boundariesElement"preventOverflow docs/a./td

div class="bd-callout bd-callout-warning"
Data attributes for individual popovers

Options for individual popovers can alternatively be specified through the use of data attributes, as explained above.
/div

 Methods

{{include 'calloutDangerAsyncMethods.html'}}

$().popover(options)

Initializes popovers for an element collection.

 .popover('show')

Reveals an element's popover. Returns to the caller before the popover has actually been shown (i.e. before the shown.bs.popover event occurs). This is considered a "manual" triggering of the popover. Popovers whose both title and content are zero-length are never displayed.

{{ highlight html }}$('#element').popover('show'){{ /highlight }}

.popover('hide')

Hides an element's popover. Returns to the caller before the popover has actually been hidden (i.e. before the hidden.bs.popover event occurs). This is considered a "manual" triggering of the popover.

{{ highlight html }}$('element').popover('hide'){{ /highlight }}

.popover('toggle')

Toggles an element's popover. Returns to the caller before the popover has actually been shown or hidden (i.e. before the shown.bs.popover or hidden.bs.popover event occurs). This is considered a "manual" triggering of the popover.

{{ highlight html }}$('element').popover('toggle'){{ /highlight }}

.popover('dispose')

Hides and destroys an element's popover. Popovers that use delegation (which are created using the selector option) cannot be individually destroyed on descendant trigger elements.

{{ highlight html }}$('element').popover('dispose'){{ /highlight }}

.popover('enable')

Gives an element's popover the ability to be shown. Popovers are enabled by default.

{{ highlight html }}$('element').popover('enable'){{ /highlight }}

.popover('disable')

Removes the ability for an element's popover to be shown. The popover will only be able to be shown if it is re-enabled.

{{ highlight html }}$('element').popover('disable'){{ /highlight }}

.popover('toggleEnabled')

Toggles the ability for an element's popover to be shown or hidden.

{{ highlight html }}$('element').popover('toggleEnabled'){{ /highlight }}

.popover('update')

Updates the position of an element's popover.

{{ highlight html }}$('element').popover('update'){{ /highlight }}

Events

    /tr
  /thead

      tdshow.bs.popover/td
      tdThis event fires immediately when the codeshow/code instance method is called./td
    /tr
    tr
      tdshown.bs.popover/td
      tdThis event is fired when the popover has been made visible to the user (will wait for CSS transitions to complete)./td
    /tr
    tr
      tdhide.bs.popover/td
      tdThis event is fired immediately when the codehide/code instance method has been called./td
    /tr
    tr
      tdhidden.bs.popover/td
      tdThis event is fired when the popover has finished being hidden from the user (will wait for CSS transitions to complete)./td
    /tr
    tr
      tdinserted.bs.popover/td
      tdThis event is fired after the codeshow.bs.popover/code event when the popover template has been added to the DOM./td
    /tr
  /tbody
/table

  // do something…
})

---
layout: docs
title: Progress
description: Documentation and examples for using framekit custom progress bars featuring support for stacked bars, animated backgrounds, and text labels.
group: components
toc: true
---

How it works

Progress components are built with two HTML elements, some CSS to set the width, and a few attributes. We don't use the HTML5 progress element, ensuring you can stack progress bars, animate them, and place text labels over them.

We use the .progress as a wrapper to indicate the max value of the progress bar.
We use the inner .progress-bar to indicate the progress so far.
The .progress-bar requires an inline style, utility class, or custom CSS to set their width.
The .progress-bar also requires some role and aria attributes to make it accessible.

Put that all together, and you have the following examples.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" aria-valuenow="0" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" style="width: 25%" aria-valuenow="25" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" style="width: 50%" aria-valuenow="50" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" style="width: 75%" aria-valuenow="75" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" style="width: 100%" aria-valuenow="100" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

framekit provides a handful of utilities for setting width. Depending on your needs, these may help with quickly configuring progress.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-w-75" role="progressbar" aria-valuenow="75" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Labels

Add labels to your progress bars by placing text within the .progress-bar.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" style="width: 25%;" aria-valuenow="25" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"25%/div
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Height

We only set a height value on the .progress, so if you change that value the inner .progress-bar will automatically resize accordingly.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-progress" style="height: 1px;"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" style="width: 25%;" aria-valuenow="25" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress" style="height: 20px;"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" style="width: 25%;" aria-valuenow="25" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Backgrounds

Use background utility classes to change the appearance of individual progress bars.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-bg-success" role="progressbar" style="width: 25%" aria-valuenow="25" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-bg-info" role="progressbar" style="width: 50%" aria-valuenow="50" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-bg-warning" role="progressbar" style="width: 75%" aria-valuenow="75" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-bg-danger" role="progressbar" style="width: 100%" aria-valuenow="100" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Multiple bars

Include multiple progress bars in a progress component if you need.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar" role="progressbar" style="width: 15%" aria-valuenow="15" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-bg-success" role="progressbar" style="width: 30%" aria-valuenow="30" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-bg-info" role="progressbar" style="width: 20%" aria-valuenow="20" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Striped

Add .progress-bar-striped to any .progress-bar to apply a stripe via CSS gradient over the progress bar's background shared.color.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-progress-bar-striped" role="progressbar" style="width: 10%" aria-valuenow="10" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-progress-bar-striped fk-bg-success" role="progressbar" style="width: 25%" aria-valuenow="25" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-progress-bar-striped fk-bg-info" role="progressbar" style="width: 50%" aria-valuenow="50" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-progress-bar-striped fk-bg-warning" role="progressbar" style="width: 75%" aria-valuenow="75" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-progress-bar-striped fk-bg-danger" role="progressbar" style="width: 100%" aria-valuenow="100" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100"/div
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Animated stripes

The striped gradient can also be animated. Add .fk-progress-bar-animated to .progress-bar to animate the stripes right to left via CSS3 animations.

div class="bd-example"
  div class="fk-progress"
    div class="fk-progress-bar fk-progress-bar-striped" role="progressbar" aria-valuenow="75" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100" style="width: 75%"/div
  /div
  button type="button" class="fk-btn fk-btn-secondary bd-toggle-animated-progress" data-toggle="button" aria-pressed="false" autocomplete="off"
    Toggle animation
  /button
/div

{{ highlight html }}
div class="fk-progress"
  div class="fk-progress-bar fk-progress-bar-striped fk-progress-bar-animated" role="progressbar" aria-valuenow="75" aria-valuemin="0" aria-valuemax="100" style="width: 75%"/div
/div
{{ /highlight }}

---
layout: docs
title: Scrollspy
description: Automatically update framekit navigation or list group components based on scroll position to indicate which link is currently active in the viewport.
group: components
toc: true
---

How it works

Scrollspy has a few requirements to function properly:

If you're building our JavaScript from source, it requires util.js.
It must be used on a framekit nav component or list group.
Scrollspy requires position: relative; on the element you're spying on, usually the body.
When spying on elements other than the body, be sure to have a height set and overflow-y: scroll; applied.
Anchors (a) are required and must point to an element with that id.

When successfully implemented, your nav or list group will update accordingly, moving the .active class from one item to the next based on their associated targets.

 Example in navbar

Scroll the area below the navbar and watch the active class change. The dropdown items will be highlighted as well.

Usage

 Via data attributes

To easily add scrollspy behavior to your topbar navigation, add data-spy="scroll" to the element you want to spy on (most typically this would be the body). Then add the data-target attribute with the ID or class of the parent element of any framekit .nav component.

{{ highlight css }}
body {
  position: relative;
}
{{ /highlight }}

{{ highlight html }}
body data-spy="scroll" data-target="#navbar-example"
  ...
  div id="navbar-example"
    ul class="nav nav-tabs" role="tablist"
      ...
    /ul
  /div
  ...
/body
{{ /highlight }}

Via JavaScript

After adding position: relative; in your CSS, call the scrollspy via JavaScript:

{{ highlight html }}
$('body').scrollspy({ target: 'navbar-example' })
{{ /highlight }}

div class="bd-callout bd-callout-warning"
Resolvable ID targets required

Navbar links must have resolvable id targets. For example, a a href="home"home/a must correspond to something in the DOM like div id="home"/div.
/div
{{include "callout" content=callout type="danger"}}

div class="bd-callout bd-callout-warning"
Non-:visible target elements ignored

Target elements that are not :visible according to jQuery will be ignored and their corresponding nav items will never be highlighted.
/div

 Methods

.scrollspy('refresh')

When using scrollspy in conjunction with adding or removing of elements from the DOM, you'll need to call the refresh method like so:

{{ highlight html }}
$('[data-spy="scroll"]').each(function () {
  var $spy = $(this).scrollspy('refresh')
})
{{ /highlight }}

 .scrollspy('dispose')

Destroys an element's scrollspy.

Options

Options can be passed via data attributes or JavaScript. For data attributes, append the option name to data-, as in data-offset="".

      tdPixels to offset from top when calculating position of scroll./td
    /tr
  /tbody
/table

 Events

table class="fk-table fk-table-bordered fk-table-striped"
  thead
    tr
      th style="width: 150px;"Event Type/th
      thDescription/th
    /tr
  /thead
  tbody
    tr
      tdactivate.bs.scrollspy/td
      tdThis event fires on the scroll element whenever a new item becomes activated by the scrollspy./td
    /tr
  /tbody
/table

{{ highlight html }}
$('[data-spy="scroll"]').on('activate.bs.scrollspy', function () {
  // do something…
})
{{ /highlight }}

title: Getting Started
date: 2019-02-23T14:32:48-06:00
weight: 5
chapter: true
pre: bX. /b
---

Chapter X

 Some Chapter title

Lorem Ipsum.

Accessibility Checklist
Framekit is built to be accessible and inclusive out-of-the-box. We follow a set of guidelines for user experience that should be used while using framekit. 
The first of these is called... 

 Common Heuristics
We follow Nielsen Norman Group's 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design

Visibility of System Status
Show the user where, when, and how they are at. The user should be able to tell the status of items and the where they are in a "flow"

 Match between system and the real world 
With Blueprint and Framekit, we follow a metaphor (within reason) of elements within a home, and how they are affected by light. Users should instantly recognize what elements/components do and not be negatively suprised by interactions.

User control and freedom 
While we only provide the CSS/HTML to create a product, we have thought about how elements should support a user's ability to edit, undo, and escape from unwanted interactions. 

 Consistency and standards
Because Framekit is built off of the atomic level design of Blueprint, we can carry design language and guidelines through-out Framekit and deliver the same colors/typefaces/design through-out.

Error Prevention 
With rules for recognition, and thought put into error/warning/and success messaging, we can help to eliminate errors through the interface.

 Recognition rather than recall
Users should be able to instantly recognize an element/component's function. 

Flexibility and efficiency of use
Power users and new users will use elements in your product. We have built components and layouts that support both.

 Aesthetic and minimalist design
No mystery meat navigation or frilly elements. We're focused on speed and usability first. Of course our design system is beautiful, but it's also functional. 

Help users recognize, diagnose, and recover from errors
We provide a multitude of ways to see alerts, notifications, and messaging.

 Help and documentation
That's why you're here right? If a small team of CSS guys can provide help to you, you can provide help/documentation to your product's users. Right?

A11Y/WebAIM Checklist
The following checklist items were built with the following links as a reference. 
https://a11yproject.com/checklist br /
https://davatron5000.github.io/a11y- nutrition-cards/br /
https://webaim.org/standards/wcag/checklistbr /
Aria rolesbr /

{{ highlight html }}
header role="banner"
{{ /highlight }}

A region of the page that is site focused. Typically your global page header.

{{ highlight html }}
nav role="navigation"
{{ /highlight }}

Contains links to navigate to different pages of a website, screens of an application, or a sections within a single document.

{{ highlight html }}
main role="main"
{{ /highlight }}

Wraps the focal content of document. Use only once.

{{ highlight html }}
article role="article"
{{ /highlight }}

Represents an independent item of content. There may be many articles in a single document. articles are not considered landmarks, but screen readers may still surface articles when navigating by regions or landmarks in a document.

{{ highlight html }}
aside role="complementary"
{{ /highlight }}

Supporting section related to the main content even when separated.

{{ highlight html }}
footer role="contentinfo"
{{ /highlight }}

Contains information about the document (meta info, copyright, company info, etc).

{{ highlight html }}
form role="search"
{{ /highlight }}

Add a search role to your primary search

 Text

Blocks of text should be no more than 80 characters wide. (For AAA compliance)
Blocks of text are NOT fully justified (aligned to both the left and the right margins). (For AAA compliance)
Blocks of text have adequate line spacing (at least 1/2 the height of the text) and paragraph spacing (1.5 times line spacing). (For AAA compliance)
Blocks of text do NOT require horizontal scrolling when the text size is doubled. (For AAA compliance)
Blocks of text have no loss of content or functionality occurs when the user adapts text line height/spacing to 1.5 times the font size, paragraph spacing to 2 times the font size, word spacing to .16 times the font size, and letter spacing to .12 times the font size. (AA)
Language
br /

{{ highlight html }}
html lang="en"
{{ /highlight }}

Specify a language with the lang attribute on the html element.

 Keyboard

All page functionality is available using the keyboard.

Timing

If a page or application has a time limit, the user is given options to turn off, adjust, or extend that time limit. This is not a requirement for real-time events (e.g., an auction), where the time limit is absolutely required, or if the time limit is longer than 20 hours.
Automatically moving, blinking, or scrolling content (such as carousels, marquees, or animations) that lasts longer than 5 seconds can be paused, stopped, or hidden by the user.
Automatically updating content (e.g., a dynamically-updating news ticker, chat messages, etc.) can be paused, stopped, or hidden by the user or the user can manually control the timing of the updates.
Interruptions (alerts, page updates, etc.) can be postponed or suppressed by the user.
If an authentication session expires, the user can re-authenticate and continue the activity without losing any data from the current page.
Users must be warned of any timeout that could result in data loss, unless the data is preserved for longer than 20 hours of user inactivity.
No page content flashes more than 3 times per second unless that flashing content is sufficiently small and the flashes are of low contrast and do not contain too much red. (See general flash and red flash thresholds)
No page content flashes more than 3 times per second.
Users can disable non-essential animation and movement that is triggered by user interaction.

 Document Outline
Use semantic headings and structure

Links
Ensure links have :focus state.
Ensure links are recognizable (underlined). (For AAA Compliance)
Provide a “Skip to main content” link.

 Images
Use appropriate alt text.
Images that do not convey content, are decorative, or contain content that is already conveyed in text are given null alt text (alt="") or implemented as CSS backgrounds. All linked images have descriptive alternative text.
Equivalent alternatives to complex images are provided in context or on a separate linked page.
Javascript
Use unobtrusive JavaScript (never use in line scripting).
Provide alternatives for users who do not have JavaScript enabled and for environments where JavaScript is unavailable.
 Forms
Logical layout
Tab order of the form follows a logical pattern.
Associated label for all form controls (e.g. input, select etc.) (text labels)

(e.g. label for="name"Name:/labelinput id="name" type="text")

Make sure placeholder attributes are not being used in place of label tags.
An exception to this rule would be smaller forms with one or two fields (eg. search or log in forms)
Group related form elements with fieldset and describe the group with legend
Important for input type="radio" and input type="checkbox"

Media (Audio and Video)
Provide text transcripts (descriptive and audio)
Synchronized subtitles for videos
Audio descriptions are provided for all video content
NOTE: Only required if the video conveys content visually that is not presented via the audio track.
A sign language video is provided for all media content that contains audio. (Optional and AAA)
When audio description cannot be added to video due to audio timing (e.g., insufficient pauses in the audio), an alternative version of the video with pauses that allow audio descriptions is provided. (Optional and AAA)
Audio with speech has no or very low background noise so the speech is easily distinguished. (For AAA compliance)

 Color and Contrast
Text and images of text have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1\. (AA)
Large text - at least 18 point (typically 24px) or 14 point (typically 18.66px) and bold - has a contrast ratio of at least 3:1\. (AA)
Test for different types of color blindness.

Deuteranopia
Protanopia
Tritanopia

Testing
Test using a screen reader
Test using keyboard only
Significant HTML/XHTML validation/parsing errors are avoided. Check at http://validator.w3.org/

 Elements (not found above)
Accordion
https://davatron5000.github.io/a11y-nutrition-cards/#accordion
Headers should have visible focus state
Integrate keyboard expectations

Enter or Space = Expands/Collapses Panel
Tab = Move to next focusable element
Shift + Tab = Move to previous focusable element
↑ ! = Cycle headers when header focused
Home (Optional) = Focus first header
End (Optional) = Focus last header

Each accordion header title is contained in an element with role button
Each accordion header button wrapped with role heading set to appropriate aria-level.
If the accordion panel is visible, the header button element should have aria-expanded set to true. If the panel is not visible, aria-expanded is set to false.
Accordion header buttons have aria-controls set to the ID of the associated accordion panel content.

Button
https://davatron5000.github.io/a11y-nutrition-cards/components/button
Integrate keyboard expectations

Enter or Space = Activate Button
Has role of button (e.g.  button )
Clear, non-repetitive label. By default this is the text content inside the element, but can be aria-labelledby or aria-label

 Disclosure

https://davatron5000.github.io/a11y-nutrition-cards/#disclosure-show-hide

Integrate keyboard expectations
Enter or Space = Toggle content
Trigger has visible keyboard :focus state
Trigger has role of button (e.g.  button )
When content is visible, button has aria-expanded set to true. When content is hidden, it is set to false.
(Optional) button references content with aria-controls

Menu & Menu Button
Integrate keyboard expectations

Enter or Space = Open Menu
Escape = Close Active Menu
! = Open Menu (when button focused)
↑↓ = Cycles menu option focus
Home (Optional) = Focus first Menu item
End (Optional) = Focus last Menu item

Menu Button and Menu options should have a visible keyboard :focus state
When escape key Escape is pressed and the menu is active/open, focus should be returned to the Menu Button associated with that menu.

(Optional) When focused on the last menu item, the down arrow key ↓
should move focus to the first menu item.
(Optional) When focused on the first menu item, the up arrow key ↑ should move focus to the last menu item.
Menu Button should use role button and use a button element to activate the menu (e.g.  button ).
Menu Button has aria-haspopup set to true.
Menu has role menu.
When menu is visible, button has aria-expanded set to true. When menu is hidden, it is set to false.
(Optional) Menu Button has aria-controls attribute that refers to the Menu
Menu visibility should be toggled using the hidden attribute.
Menu items should use the appropriate roles, states, and properties depending their functionality. More on that here.

!-- image](Design%20System%20Checklist/Image_091.png) --
 Tabs 
Integrate keyboard expectations

Space or Enter = Activate Tab
←→ = Cycles tab focus
↑↓ = Cycles tab focus (vertical tabs)
Home = Focus first tab
End = Focus last tab

Tabs should activate automatically when receiving focus as long as associated tab panels are rendered quickly.
Tabs should have visible :focus state.
Tabs should have visible aria-selected="true" state
The element that wraps tabs has role tablist.
Each tab has role tab and is contained within the element with role tablist.
Each tab content panel has role tabpanel.
The active tab has aria-selected set to true and all other tab elements have it set to false.
Each tabpanel has the property aria-labelledby referring to its associated tab.

Tooltips
Integrate keyboard expectations

ESC - Dismisses tooltip

Focus stays on tooltip trigger while the tooltip is displayed.

If the tooltip is invoked when the trigger receives focus, then it is dismissed when it no longer has focus (onBlur). If the tooltip is invoked with mouseIn, then it is dismissed with on mouseOut.
Tooltip content container has role tooltip
Tooltip trigger references the tooltip element with aria-describedby

 CSS checklist

Validation
https://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/

 Browsers

Google Chrome
Blink (Besides Chrome)
Firefox
Webkit
Safari
IE 11
Edge

Check features against https://caniuse.com/

Is my normalize working correctly
fallback working
Are units in %, em, or rem?

Media Queries
Have I added code meta name = “viewport” content = “width=device-width”  ? /code
Are files minified for the production version

We've designed and developed framekit to work in a number of environments. Here are some of the best practices we've gathered from years of working on and using it ourselves.

---

Browser Support

We aim to support browsers who have global coverage of 1%. It's set in the package.json and you can verify our current selections against Browserlist

{{ highlight html }}
"browserslist": [
  "last 1 major version",
  "= 1%",
  "Chrome = 45",
  "Firefox = 38",
  "Edge = 12",
  "Explorer = 10",
  "iOS = 9",
  "Safari = 9",
  "Android = 4.4",
  "Opera = 30"
]
{{ /highlight }}

 Mobile devices

While we do support mobile devices through "mobile first" css and "mobile first" thinking, we are focused on delivering desktop (and larger!) interfaces for our office driven applications.

---
layout: docs
title: Build tools
description: Learn how to use framekit's included npm scripts to build our documentation, compile source code, run tests, and more.
group: getting-started
toc: true
---

BELOW IS NOT FROM FRAMEKIT

Tooling setup

framekit uses NPM scripts for its build system. Our package.json includes convenient methods for working with the framework, including compiling code, running tests, and more.

To use our build system and run our documentation locally, you'll need a copy of framekit's source files and Node. Follow these steps and you should be ready to rock:

Download and install Node.js, which we use to manage our dependencies.
Navigate to the root /framekit directory and run npm install to install our local dependencies listed in package.json.
Install Ruby, install Bundler with gem install bundler, and finally run bundle install. This will install all Ruby dependencies, such as Jekyll and plugins.
  Windows users: Read this guide to get Jekyll up and running without problems.

When completed, you'll be able to run the various commands provided from the command line.

[install-ruby]: https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/documentation/installation/
[gembundler]: https://bundler.io/

 Using NPM scripts

Our package.json includes the following commands and tasks:

| Task | Description |
| --- | --- |
| npm run dist | npm run dist creates the /dist directory with compiled files. Uses Sass, Autoprefixer, and UglifyJS. |
| npm test | Same as npm run dist plus it runs tests locally |
| npm run docs | Builds and lints CSS and JavaScript for docs. You can then run the documentation locally via npm run docs-serve. |

Run npm run to see all the npm scripts.

Autoprefixer

framekit uses Autoprefixer (included in our build process) to automatically add vendor prefixes to some CSS properties at build time. Doing so saves us time and code by allowing us to write key parts of our CSS a single time while eliminating the need for vendor mixins like those found in v3.

We maintain the list of browsers supported through Autoprefixer in a separate file within our GitHub repository. See /package.json for details.

 Local documentation

Running our documentation locally requires the use of Jekyll, a decently flexible static site generator that provides us: basic includes, Markdown-based files, templates, and more. Here's how to get it started:

Run through the tooling setup above to install Jekyll (the site builder) and other Ruby dependencies with bundle install.
From the root /framekit directory, run npm run docs-serve in the command line.
Open http://localhost:9001 in your browser, and voilà.

Learn more about using Jekyll by reading its documentation.

Troubleshooting

Should you encounter problems with installing dependencies, uninstall all previous dependency versions (global and local). Then, rerun npm install.

[autoprefixer]: https://github.com/postcss/autoprefixer

---
layout: docs
title: Contents
description: Discover what's included in framekit, including our precompiled and source code flavors. Remember, framekit's JavaScript plugins require jQuery.
group: getting-started
toc: true
---

Precompiled framekit

Once downloaded, unzip the compressed folder and you'll see something like this:

!-- NOTE: This info is intentionally duplicated in the README. Copy any changes made here over to the README too. --

{{ highlight html }}
framekit/
├── css/
│   ├── framekit.css
│   ├── framekit.css.map
│   ├── framekit.min.css
│   ├── framekit.min.css.map
│   ├── framekit-grid.css
│   ├── framekit-grid.css.map
│   ├── framekit-grid.min.css
│   ├── framekit-grid.min.css.map
│   ├── framekit-reboot.css
│   ├── framekit-reboot.css.map
│   ├── framekit-reboot.min.css
│   └── framekit-reboot.min.css.map
└── js/
    ├── framekit.bundle.js
    ├── framekit.bundle.min.js
    ├── framekit.js
    └── framekit.min.js
{{ /highlight }}

This is the most basic form of framekit: precompiled files for quick drop-in usage in nearly any web project. We provide compiled CSS and JS (framekit.), as well as compiled and minified CSS and JS (framekit.min.). CSS source maps (framekit.*.map) are available for use with certain browsers' developer tools. Bundled JS files (framekit.bundle.js and minified framekit.bundle.min.js) include Popper, but not jQuery.

 CSS files

framekit includes a handful of options for including some or all of our compiled CSS.

{{ highlight html }}

        divcode class="fk-font-weight-normal fk-text-nowrap"framekit.min.css/code/div
      /th
      td class="fk-text-success"Included/td
      td class="fk-text-success"Included/td
      td class="fk-text-success"Included/td
      td class="fk-text-success"Included/td
    /tr
    tr
      th scope="row"
        divcode class="fk-font-weight-normal fk-text-nowrap"framekit-grid.css/code/div
        divcode class="fk-font-weight-normal fk-text-nowrap"framekit-grid.min.css/code/div
      /th
      tda class="fk-text-warning" href="{{ shared.server.baseurl }}/docs/{{ shared.docs_version }}/layout/grid/"Only grid system/a/td
      td class="fk-bg-light fk-text-muted"Not included/td
      td class="fk-bg-light fk-text-muted"Not included/td
      tda class="fk-text-warning" href="{{ shared.server.baseurl }}/docs/{{ shared.docs_version }}/utilities/flex/"Only flex utilities/a/td

      /th
      td class="fk-bg-light fk-text-muted"Not included/td

JS files

Similarly, we have options for including some or all of our compiled JavaScript.

{{ highlight html }}

table class="fk-table fk-table-bordered"
  thead
    tr
      th scope="col"JS files/th

    /tr

  tbody
    tr
      th scope="row"

      td class="fk-text-success"Included/td
      td class="fk-bg-light fk-text-muted"Not included/td

    /tr
  /tbody

{{ /highlight }}

 Framekit source code

The Framekit source code download includes the precompiled CSS and JavaScript assets, along with source Sass, JavaScript, and documentation. More specifically, it includes the following and more:

{{ highlight plaintext }}
framekit/
├── dist/
│   ├── css/
│   └── js/
├── docs/
│   └── examples/
├── js/
└── scss/
{{ /highlight }}

The scss/ and js/ are the source code for our CSS and JavaScript. The dist/ folder includes everything listed in the precompiled download section above. The docs/ folder includes the source code for our documentation, and examples/ of framekit usage. Beyond that, any other included file provides support for packages, license information, and development.

title: Download
content:
Download Framekit

How to Best Use Framekit

!! To run the kitchen dev previewer and to compile or build the system you will need SSH Key to be added to your profile in bitbucket

 Quick Start

In terminal, cd to the directory of choice

Clone, by running git clone ssh://git@bitbucket:7999/flk/cxd-ds-framekit.git

Run npm install to get dependencies

Run gulp build as a means to test whether or not the project will compile correctly
npm start To start complete system with watches and server

Note: on at least a weekly basis, make sure you run npm update to make sure that all of your modules (tokens etc. ) are updated

Commands

    gulp start

Maps & Builds tokens and SASS files. Runs the Kitchen previewer and starts watches for changes in all files. Files are placed in build folder.

    gulp build 

(default) Maps tokens from the tokens folder and all components folders and then converts into to the _framekit-tokens.scss file and places it in the src/globals/scss folder. Also Maps SASS files in the toolkit global folders, components, utilities and then converts them into a build folder.

---
title: CSS Overview
---

CSS Overview

 Framekit follows a ITCSS flavor CSS architecture and is setup in the following structure:
br /
i End the Specificity Wars!/i

Globals: A container for assets that are used throughout the framekit. Ex: images, js, fonts, etc.

Globals/Settings: Hold core Token and Framework variables, settings and config information. In the Globals folder

Globals/Tools: Globally used mixins and functions. In the Globals folder

---- First two layers are for pre-processors and should not output any CSS. ---- br /
Globals/Base: Normalize styles, box-sizing definition. Entire purpose here is to normalize native elements across browser so we have a standard canvas to work with. (First layer to output css)

Globals/Elements: Bare global elements styling. Last layer to call native HTML tags without being conisdered a hack.

Shared: Shortcut code like extendable classes or mixins (opinionated to the design system)

Objects - class-based selectors defining undecorated design patterns. Layout containers, grid, media object, etc.

Components - Discrete, complete chunks of UI. Majority of the work happens here.

Utilities - High-specificity, very explicit selectors, helper classes with the ability to override anything which goes before it above. !importants are allowed here.

Important Notes

The order of individual items in each layer does not (and shouldnt) matter. However the order of the layers themselves are important to prevent the dreaded specificity war
Due to the above, the setting layer must be pure data and cannot depend on mixins or functions.
a FUTURE layer will include Theme layer

* Adding Mixins close to context To enable the inclusion of mixins available to the whole system, but be included into the tools layer to ensure their availability through the import chain, prefix the file name with _tools. and the build system will grab it and generate the @import with the tools. Remember these files should not output any CSS

More about ITCSS

ITCSS stands for Inverted Triangle CSS and helps Blueprint organize CSS files in a way CSS global namespace,cascade and selector specificity.

Why structure this way? It allows us to take advantage of inheritance, instead of battling against just overwriting styles. This reduces css we need to write and maintain.

It also outputs effecient CSS thats clear and concise for developers ramping up later. Scaling is simple. Your adding code but not more complexity.

 With this structure, you stop asking if your are styling a color or typography element but rather ask what is the scope of the element your working on. If its an element that appears elsewhere you know its towards the top of the stylesheet. If its a pattern appearing very specificially it will be towards the bottom.

 Key Concepts

Write CSS in specificity order
Make rules additive, not overiding.
Order imports following the triangle, starting with wide-reaching / low specificity and working towards low-reach / high-specificity rules

Organize by these key metrics

 Generic to explicit

Start with Most-generic, low-level and catch-all styles the move to more specific and explicit rules. Ex: Start with a normalize, progress to ul, p, h1-6 through exlicit utilities like .u-align-right.

Low specificity to high specificity

Lowest-specificity selectors appear towards the top, and then specificity increases slowly prgressing through the styles. We avoid writing higher-specificity selectors before the lower ones.

 Far-reaching to localised

At the beginning selectors affect a large portion of the DOM and then that gets lessened as we go deeper.

For more information on ITCSS, read https://www.xfive.co/blog/itcss-scalable-maintainable-css-architecture/

---
order: 1
title: Introduction to Framekit
lead: Framekit is Fannie Mae's web implementaiton of the Blueprint Design System
---

This is Framekit

 What is Framekit?

Framekit is the web expression of the Blueprint Design System and Design Language. It's a framework-agnostic scalable sass-based css framework to streamline development of web tools in Fannie Mae's Digital Products portfolio and application frameworks like ADK. 

Framekit is a UI Toolkit with HTML components, SASS, and CSS, and it is a framework built upon standards and ideologies from Fannie Mae’s Blueprint Design System. It was designed/coded alongside Blueprint, and it uses the Design System’s Tokens at its core as a major dependency.

Why should we use Framekit?

Framekit will allow you to get up and running with the design system integrated into your code. The ADK uses Framekit and the Blueprint tokens as a part of its dependencies. So whether you use HTML/CSS. Or SASS or Native Web Components or Angular components from the ADK, you'll be up-and-running  easily.

 Goals of Framekit

Framekit was designed with certain goals in mind: Provide developers with an easy means of getting designed components and code that matches Blueprint.

We intend to give developers utilities, components and helpers that allow them to focus on logic code and not layout.

Feature Support

For Feature compatability and browser support see https://caniuse.com

 Naming Conventions

o- Layout / Objects consider d- or o-
c- Components
u- Utilities (then follows CTI naming)
js- Classes witch influence behavior of an element through JS. This way we know explicitly where JS dependencies
qa- Quality assurance styles, testing purposes,
docs- Styles for just documentation of the system itself and not meant for production use.
_ Outright Hacks

States

is- / has- Temporary States. This is was JS can add and remove.
    is-active
    is-open
    has-items
    is-hovered

* yet to be used, so not set in stone *

env- Enviroment
mode- Like Enviroment, Mode.
t- theme

General Guidelines

 Apply Margins in same direction, when possible.

Prefer applying margins to the bottom and right

Applying spacing with 3 C's

To help understand how to apply the Blueprint Spacing grid its broken down to Containers, Content, Components

 Containers

Are the frames of your UI and hold content. Ex: Pages, Cards, Modals, Tiles, etc.

Ideal Spacing to use Padding all around, using the inset, stretch, or squish spacing variables.

 NOTE: containers are sometimes used to space out

Content

Content lives inside containers. Often mixed with data, examples are paragraphs, lists, forms, tables. Many are leaf-node hierarchy.

Ideal Spacing to use Margins to the bottom, using the stack spacing variables

leaf-node types to solve for at Fannie Mae

Lists
Tables
Forms
Paragraphs

 NOTE: These elements most often than not add margin collisions with line-height adding extra spacing. Effort is being made to solve all these with calculated measures via mixins.

 Components

Are items like buttons, input fields, icons. They are often placed next to each other horizontally inline.

Ideal Spacing to use Margins to the right, using the line spacing variables.

 NOTE: Attempt to align components and type is perfectly on baseline grid and proportionately spaced to create hormonious aligned layout.

div

Within the actual names of our CSS classes, we use a BEM naming structure. Please see: https://css-tricks.com/bem-101/ for more info on BEM naming

/div

title: General Principles
---

THIS IS NOT FROM FRAMEKIT TKTKTK

blockquote class="c-blockquote"
Part of being a good steward to a successful project is realizing that writing code for yourself is a bad idea. If thousands of people are using your code, then write your code for maximum clarity, not your personal preference of how to get clever within the spec. — Idan Gazit
/blockquote

Favor clarity over brevity
While it may be tempting to create shortcut names and acronyms as they may be familuar with you and the team now, but will that acronym be easiely understandable and its reltation to everyone else a year from now.

 Keep thinking Modular.
While it may be tempting to create shortcut names and acronyms as they may be familuar with you and the team now, but will that acronym be easiely understandable and its reltation to everyone else a year from now.

Our Goal
Work to together, unified to:
Keep Stylesheets scalable
Keep code readable and consistent
Keep code sane
Keep stylesheets maintainable
Make it understandable for a developer a year from now to read the code and know how to contrubute.

title: About
date: 2019-02-23T14:18:31-06:00

pre: bX. /b
---

TKTKTK THIS IS FROM MAILCHIMP AND TWITTER

Have a need for framekit's brand resources? Great! We have only a few guidelines we follow, and in turn ask you to follow as well. These guidelines were inspired by MailChimp's Brand Assets.

Mark and logo

Use either the framekit mark (a capital B**) or the standard logo (just **framekit). It should always appear in San Francisco Display Semibold. Do not use the Twitter bird in association with framekit.

div class="fk-brand-logos"
  div class="fk-brand-item"
    img class="svg" src="{{shared.server.baseurl }}/assets/brand/framekit-solid.svg" alt="framekit" width="144" height="144"
  /div
  div class="fk-brand-item fk-inverse"
    img class="svg" src="{{shared.server.baseurl }}/assets/brand/framekit-outline.svg" alt="framekit" width="144" height="144"
  /div
/div
div class="fk-brand-logos"
  div class="fk-brand-item"
    span class="fk-h1"framekit/span
  /div
  div class="fk-brand-item fk-inverse"
    span class="fk-h1"framekit/span
  /div
/div

 Download mark

Download the framekit mark in one of three styles, each available as an SVG file. Right click, Save as.

div class="fk-brand-logos"
  div class="fk-brand-item"
    img class="svg" src="{{shared.server.baseurl }}/assets/brand/framekit-solid.svg" alt="framekit" width="144" height="144"
  /div
  div class="fk-brand-item fk-inverse"
    img class="svg" src="{{shared.server.baseurl }}/assets/brand/framekit-outline.svg" alt="framekit" width="144" height="144"
  /div
  div class="fk-brand-item fk-inverse"
    img class="svg" src="{{shared.server.baseurl }}/assets/brand/framekit-punchout.svg" alt="framekit" width="144" height="144"
  /div
/div

Name

The project and framework should always be referred to as framekit. No Twitter before it, no capital _s_, and no abbreviations except for one, a capital *B*.

    strong class="fk-text-warning"Wrong/strong
  /div
/div

 Colors

Our docs and branding use a handful of primary colors to differentiate what is framekit from what is in framekit. In other words, if it's purple, it's representative of framekit.

  /div
/div

THIS IS FROM MAILCHIMP

Mark and logo

Use either the framekit mark (a capital B**) or the standard logo (just **framekit). It should always appear in San Francisco Display Semibold. Do not use the Twitter bird in association with framekit.

        "uri": "/src/content/about/index",
        "content": "---
title: Overview
date:  2019-02-23T14:30:19-06:00
weight: 5
chapter: about
---

THIS IS FROM BOOTSTRAP

Team

framekit is maintained by a small team of developers on GitHub. We're actively looking to grow this team and would love to hear from you if you're excited about CSS at scale, writing and maintaining vanilla JavaScript plugins, and improving build tooling processes for frontend code.

 History

Originally created by a designer and a developer at Twitter, framekit has become one of the most popular front-end frameworks and open source projects in the world.

framekit was created at Twitter in mid-2010 by @mdo and @fat. Prior to being an open-sourced framework, framekit was known as Twitter Blueprint. A few months into development, Twitter held its first Hack Week and the project exploded as developers of all skill levels jumped in without any external guidance. It served as the style guide for internal tools development at the company for over a year before its public release, and continues to do so today.

Originally released on time datetime="2011-08-19 11:25"Friday, August 19, 2011/time, we've since had over twenty releases, including two major rewrites with v2 and v3. With framekit 2, we added responsive functionality to the entire framework as an optional stylesheet. Building on that with framekit 3, we rewrote the library once more to make it responsive by default with a mobile first approach.

With framekit 4, we once again rewrote the project to account for two key architectural changes: a migration to Sass and the move to CSS's flexbox. Our intention is to help in a small way to move the web development community forward by pushing for newer CSS properties, fewer dependencies, and new technologies across more modern browsers.

Get involved

Get involved with framekit development by opening an issue or submitting a pull request. Read our contributing guidelines for information on how we develop.",

Redistribute any piece of framekit without proper attribution
Use any marks owned by Twitter in any way that might state or imply that Twitter endorses your distribution
Use any marks owned by Twitter in any way that might state or imply that you created the Twitter software in question

 It does not require you to:

Include the source of framekit itself, or of any modifications you may have made to it, in any redistribution you may assemble that includes it
Submit changes that you make to framekit back to the framekit project (though such feedback is encouraged)

    {
        "uri": "/src/content/components/forms/forms3",
        "content": "---
layout: docs
title: Forms
description: Examples and usage guidelines for form control styles, layout options, and custom components for creating a wide variety of forms.
group: components
toc: true
---

Overview

framekit's form controls expand on our Rebooted form styles with classes. Use these classes to opt into their customized displays for a more consistent rendering across browsers and devices.

Be sure to use an appropriate type attribute on all inputs (e.g., email for email address or number for numerical information) to take advantage of newer input controls like email verification, number selection, and more.

Here's a quick example to demonstrate framekit's form styles. Keep reading for documentation on required classes, form layout, and more.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="exampleInputEmail1"Email address/label
    input type="email" class="fk-form-control" id="exampleInputEmail1" aria-describedby="emailHelp" placeholder="Enter email"
    small id="emailHelp" class="fk-form-text fk-text-muted"We'll never share your email with anyone else./small
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="exampleInputPassword1"Password/label
    input type="password" class="fk-form-control" id="exampleInputPassword1" placeholder="Password"
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group fk-form-check"
    input type="checkbox" class="fk-form-check-input" id="exampleCheck1"
    label class="fk-form-check-label" for="exampleCheck1"Check me out/label
  /div
  button type="submit" class="fk-btn fk-btn-primary"Submit/button
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Form controls

Textual form controls—like inputs, selects, and textareas—are styled with the .form-control class. Included are styles for general appearance, focus state, sizing, and more.

Be sure to explore our custom forms to further style selects.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="exampleFormControlInput1"Email address/label
    input type="email" class="fk-form-control" id="exampleFormControlInput1" placeholder="name@example.com"
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="exampleFormControlSelect1"Example select/label
    select class="fk-form-control" id="exampleFormControlSelect1"
      option1/option
      option2/option
      option3/option
      option4/option
      option5/option
    /select
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="exampleFormControlSelect2"Example multiple select/label
    select multiple class="fk-form-control" id="exampleFormControlSelect2"
      option1/option
      option2/option
      option3/option
      option4/option
      option5/option
    /select
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="exampleFormControlTextarea1"Example textarea/label
    textarea class="fk-form-control" id="exampleFormControlTextarea1" rows="3"/textarea
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

For file inputs, swap the .form-control for .form-control-file.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="exampleFormControlFile1"Example file input/label
    input type="file" class="fk-form-control-file" id="exampleFormControlFile1"
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Sizing

Set heights using classes like .form-control-lg and .form-control-sm.

{{capture 'example'}}
input class="fk-form-control fk-form-control-lg" type="text" placeholder=".form-control-lg"
input class="fk-form-control" type="text" placeholder="Default input"
input class="fk-form-control fk-form-control-sm" type="text" placeholder=".form-control-sm"
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

{{capture 'example'}}
select class="fk-form-control fk-form-control-lg"
  optionLarge select/option
/select
select class="fk-form-control"
  optionDefault select/option
/select
select class="fk-form-control fk-form-control-sm"
  optionSmall select/option
/select
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Range Inputs

Set horizontally scrollable range inputs using .form-control-range.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="formControlRange"Example Range input/label
    input type="range" class="fk-form-control-range" id="formControlRange"
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Readonly

Add the readonly boolean attribute on an input to prevent modification of the input's value. Read-only inputs appear lighter (just like disabled inputs), but retain the standard cursor.

{{capture 'example'}}
input class="fk-form-control" type="text" placeholder="Readonly input here…" readonly
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Readonly plain text

If you want to have input readonly elements in your form styled as plain text, use the .form-control-plaintext class to remove the default form field styling and preserve the correct margin and padding.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    label for="staticEmail" class="fk-col-sm-2 fk-col-form-label"Email/label
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"
      input type="text" readonly class="fk-form-control-plaintext" id="staticEmail" value="email@example.com"
    /div
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    label for="inputPassword" class="fk-col-sm-2 fk-col-form-label"Password/label
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"
      input type="password" class="fk-form-control" id="inputPassword" placeholder="Password"
    /div
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

{{capture 'example'}}
form class="fk-form-inline"
  div class="fk-form-group fk-mb-2"
    label for="staticEmail2" class="sr-only"Email/label
    input type="text" readonly class="fk-form-control-plaintext" id="staticEmail2" value="email@example.com"
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group fk-mx-sm-3 fk-mb-2"
    label for="inputPassword2" class="sr-only"Password/label
    input type="password" class="fk-form-control" id="inputPassword2" placeholder="Password"
  /div
  button type="submit" class="fk-btn fk-btn-primary fk-mb-2"Confirm identity/button
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Checkboxes and radios

Default checkboxes and radios are improved upon with the help of .form-check, a single class for both input types that improves the layout and behavior of their HTML elements. Checkboxes are for selecting one or several options in a list, while radios are for selecting one option from many.

Disabled checkboxes and radios are supported, but to provide a not-allowed cursor on hover of the parent label, you'll need to add the disabled attribute to the .form-check-input. The disabled attribute will apply a lighter color to help indicate the input's state.

Checkboxes and radios use are built to support HTML-based form validation and provide concise, accessible labels. As such, our inputs and labels are sibling elements as opposed to an input within a label. This is slightly more verbose as you must specify id and for attributes to relate the input and label.

 Default (stacked)

By default, any number of checkboxes and radios that are immediate sibling will be vertically stacked and appropriately spaced with .form-check.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-form-check"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="checkbox" value="" id="defaultCheck1"
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="defaultCheck1"
    Default checkbox
  /label
/div
div class="fk-form-check"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="checkbox" value="" id="defaultCheck2" disabled
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="defaultCheck2"
    Disabled checkbox
  /label
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-form-check"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="exampleRadios" id="exampleRadios1" value="option1" checked
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="exampleRadios1"
    Default radio
  /label
/div
div class="fk-form-check"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="exampleRadios" id="exampleRadios2" value="option2"
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="exampleRadios2"
    Second default radio
  /label
/div
div class="fk-form-check fk-disabled"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="exampleRadios" id="exampleRadios3" value="option3" disabled
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="exampleRadios3"
    Disabled radio
  /label
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Inline

Group checkboxes or radios on the same horizontal row by adding .form-check-inline to any .form-check.

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-form-check fk-form-check-inline"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="checkbox" id="inlineCheckbox1" value="option1"
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="inlineCheckbox1"1/label
/div
div class="fk-form-check fk-form-check-inline"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="checkbox" id="inlineCheckbox2" value="option2"
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="inlineCheckbox2"2/label
/div
div class="fk-form-check fk-form-check-inline"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="checkbox" id="inlineCheckbox3" value="option3" disabled
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="inlineCheckbox3"3 (disabled)/label
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-form-check fk-form-check-inline"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="inlineRadioOptions" id="inlineRadio1" value="option1"
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="inlineRadio1"1/label
/div
div class="fk-form-check fk-form-check-inline"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="inlineRadioOptions" id="inlineRadio2" value="option2"
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="inlineRadio2"2/label
/div
div class="fk-form-check fk-form-check-inline"
  input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="inlineRadioOptions" id="inlineRadio3" value="option3" disabled
  label class="fk-form-check-label" for="inlineRadio3"3 (disabled)/label
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Without labels

Add .position-static to inputs within .form-check that don't have any label text. Remember to still provide some form of label for assistive technologies (for instance, using aria-label).

{{capture 'example'}}
div class="fk-form-check"
  input class="fk-form-check-input fk-position-static" type="checkbox" id="blankCheckbox" value="option1" aria-label="..."
/div
div class="fk-form-check"
  input class="fk-form-check-input fk-position-static" type="radio" name="blankRadio" id="blankRadio1" value="option1" aria-label="..."
/div
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Layout

Since framekit applies display: block and width: 100% to almost all our form controls, forms will by default stack vertically. Additional classes can be used to vary this layout on a per-form basis.

 Form groups

The .form-group class is the easiest way to add some structure to forms. It provides a flexible class that encourages proper grouping of labels, controls, optional help text, and form validation messaging. By default it only applies margin-bottom, but it picks up additional styles in .form-inline as needed. Use it with fieldsets, divs, or nearly any other element.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="formGroupExampleInput"Example label/label
    input type="text" class="fk-form-control" id="formGroupExampleInput" placeholder="Example input"
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="formGroupExampleInput2"Another label/label
    input type="text" class="fk-form-control" id="formGroupExampleInput2" placeholder="Another input"
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

Form grid

More complex forms can be built using our grid classes. Use these for form layouts that require multiple columns, varied widths, and additional alignment options.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-row"
    div class="fk-col"
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" placeholder="First name"
    /div
    div class="fk-col"
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" placeholder="Last name"
    /div
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Form row

You may also swap .row for .form-row, a variation of our standard grid row that overrides the default column gutters for tighter and more compact layouts.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-row"
    div class="fk-col"
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" placeholder="First name"
    /div
    div class="fk-col"
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" placeholder="Last name"
    /div
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

More complex layouts can also be created with the grid system.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-row"
    div class="fk-form-group fk-col-md-6"
      label for="inputEmail4"Email/label
      input type="email" class="fk-form-control" id="inputEmail4" placeholder="Email"
    /div
    div class="fk-form-group fk-col-md-6"
      label for="inputPassword4"Password/label
      input type="password" class="fk-form-control" id="inputPassword4" placeholder="Password"
    /div
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="inputAddress"Address/label
    input type="text" class="fk-form-control" id="inputAddress" placeholder="1234 Main St"
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group"
    label for="inputAddress2"Address 2/label
    input type="text" class="fk-form-control" id="inputAddress2" placeholder="Apartment, studio, or floor"
  /div
  div class="fk-form-row"
    div class="fk-form-group fk-col-md-6"
      label for="inputCity"City/label
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" id="inputCity"
    /div
    div class="fk-form-group fk-col-md-4"
      label for="inputState"State/label
      select id="inputState" class="fk-form-control"
        option selectedChoose.../option
        option.../option
      /select
    /div
    div class="fk-form-group fk-col-md-2"
      label for="inputZip"Zip/label
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" id="inputZip"
    /div
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group"
    div class="fk-form-check"
      input class="fk-form-check-input" type="checkbox" id="gridCheck"
      label class="fk-form-check-label" for="gridCheck"
        Check me out
      /label
    /div
  /div
  button type="submit" class="fk-btn fk-btn-primary"Sign in/button
/form

Horizontal form

Create horizontal forms with the grid by adding the .row class to form groups and using the .col-*-* classes to specify the width of your labels and controls. Be sure to add .col-form-label to your labels as well so they're vertically centered with their associated form controls.

At times, you maybe need to use margin or padding utilities to create that perfect alignment you need. For example, we've removed the padding-top on our stacked radio inputs label to better align the text baseline.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    label for="inputEmail3" class="fk-col-sm-2 fk-col-form-label"Email/label
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"
      input type="email" class="fk-form-control" id="inputEmail3" placeholder="Email"
    /div
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    label for="inputPassword3" class="fk-col-sm-2 fk-col-form-label"Password/label
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"
      input type="password" class="fk-form-control" id="inputPassword3" placeholder="Password"
    /div
  /div
  fieldset class="fk-form-group"
    div class="fk-row"
      legend class="fk-col-form-label fk-col-sm-2 fk-pt-0"Radios/legend
      div class="fk-col-sm-10"
        div class="fk-form-check"
          input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="gridRadios" id="gridRadios1" value="option1" checked
          label class="fk-form-check-label" for="gridRadios1"
            First radio
          /label
        /div
        div class="fk-form-check"
          input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="gridRadios" id="gridRadios2" value="option2"
          label class="fk-form-check-label" for="gridRadios2"
            Second radio
          /label
        /div
        div class="fk-form-check fk-disabled"
          input class="fk-form-check-input" type="radio" name="gridRadios" id="gridRadios3" value="option3" disabled
          label class="fk-form-check-label" for="gridRadios3"
            Third disabled radio
          /label
        /div
      /div
    /div
  /fieldset
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    div class="fk-col-sm-2"Checkbox/div
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"
      div class="fk-form-check"
        input class="fk-form-check-input" type="checkbox" id="gridCheck1"
        label class="fk-form-check-label" for="gridCheck1"
          Example checkbox
        /label
      /div
    /div
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"
      button type="submit" class="fk-btn fk-btn-primary"Sign in/button
    /div
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Horizontal form label sizing

Be sure to use .col-form-label-sm or .col-form-label-lg to your labels or legends to correctly follow the size of .form-control-lg and .form-control-sm.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    label for="colFormLabelSm" class="fk-col-sm-2 fk-col-form-label fk-col-form-label-sm"Email/label
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"
      input type="email" class="fk-form-control fk-form-control-sm" id="colFormLabelSm" placeholder="col-form-label-sm"
    /div
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    label for="colFormLabel" class="fk-col-sm-2 fk-col-form-label"Email/label
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"

    /div
  /div
  div class="fk-form-group fk-row"
    label for="colFormLabelLg" class="fk-col-sm-2 fk-col-form-label fk-col-form-label-lg"Email/label
    div class="fk-col-sm-10"
      input type="email" class="fk-form-control fk-form-control-lg" id="colFormLabelLg" placeholder="col-form-label-lg"
    /div

Column sizing

As shown in the previous examples, our grid system allows you to place any number of .cols within a .row or .form-row. They'll split the available width equally between them. You may also pick a subset of your columns to take up more or less space, while the remaining .cols equally split the rest, with specific column classes like .col-7.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-row"
    div class="fk-col-7"
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" placeholder="City"
    /div
    div class="fk-col"
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" placeholder="State"
    /div
    div class="fk-col"
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control" placeholder="Zip"
    /div
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

 Auto-sizing

The example below uses a flexbox utility to vertically center the contents and changes .col to .col-auto so that your columns only take up as much space as needed. Put another way, the column sizes itself based on the contents.

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-row fk-align-items-center"
    div class="fk-col-auto"
      label class="sr-only" for="inlineFormInput"Name/label
      input type="text" class="fk-form-control fk-mb-2" id="inlineFormInput" placeholder="Jane Doe"
    /div
    div class="fk-col-auto"
      label class="sr-only" for="inlineFormInputGroup"Username/label
      div class="fk-input-group fk-mb-2"
        div class="fk-input-group-prepend"
          div class="fk-input-group-text"@/div
        /div
        input type="text" class="fk-form-control" id="inlineFormInputGroup" placeholder="Username"
      /div
    /div
    div class="fk-col-auto"
      div class="fk-form-check fk-mb-2"
        input class="fk-form-check-input" type="checkbox" id="autoSizingCheck"
        label class="fk-form-check-label" for="autoSizingCheck"
          Remember me
        /label
      /div
    /div
    div class="fk-col-auto"
      button type="submit" class="fk-btn fk-btn-primary fk-mb-2"Submit/button
    /div
  /div
/form
/div
{{include 'example' content=example}}

{{capture 'example'}}
form
  div class="fk-form-row fk-align-items-center"

      label class="sr-only" for="inlineFormInputName"Name/label
